Graphical abstract TIFF Image, 2572 × 5665 pixels (h×w), 600 dpi. Although carbon-supported palladium catalysts have been generally used for the direct synthesis of H2O2 (DSHP), the low H2O2 selectivity remains a challenge. In this work, it was systematically studied how the sulfonated carbon surface affects the physicochemical properties of Pd during catalyst preparation, and thereby affects the catalytic activity of Pd/C for the DSHP reaction. Nano-sized Pd particles (about 2–3 nm) with a high Pd2+/Pd0 ratio resulted in a high H2O2 selectivity. The sulfonated carbon material acted as an efficient solid acid support and enhanced the H2O2 selectivity. Fine-tuning the Pd properties on the sulfonated carbon support significantly improved the H2O2 selectivity by as much as 87 % in the absence of caustic promoters, which clearly demonstrates that the synergistic combination of the active metal properties and that of the carbon support are extremely important to realize a highly active and selective carbon-supported palladium catalyst for the DSHP reaction. Keywords Direct synthesis of H2O2 Pd/C Surface modification Sulfonation Solid acid support 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is extensively used in the commodity, petrochemical, and environmental industry, but its potential applications extend even to other fields such as semi-conductors and military use [1–3]. While a number of methods were developed to synthesize H2O2, most of the commercial H2O2 production relies on the anthraquinone oxidation process (AO Process) [2,4–6]. However, the AO process suffers from inherent economic and environmental problems, because the process consists of high energy-demanding steps, uses large amounts of toxic chemicals, and generates excessive waste during post-treatment. Therefore, diverse chemical and electrochemical routes were pursued to find a more efficient and greener method to produce H2O2 [7–11]. The direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 (DSHP) is a simple route with the highest atom utilization efficiency. A question commonly asked during the past decades is whether this simple reaction can be a viable alternative to the AO process, thereby opening a new era of eco-friendly H2O2 production [12–17]. In particular, direct use of H2O2 in selective oxidation processes would be economically advantageous. For example, the preliminary projection of the propylene oxide (PO) production cost via propylene epoxidation with H2O2 (HPPO) indicated that the method of H2O2 supply considerably impacts the production cost [1]. The H2O2 availability in organic solvents such as methanol is another unique feature of the DSHP reaction. This approach is superior to the electrochemical way. The direct use of H2O2 via methanol as a solvent requires the water content to be minimized to suppress unfavorable ring-opening of PO. In this context, the successful DSHP implementation would be a breakthrough with respect to the selective oxidation process technology. Despite its promising outlook, the DSHP process development is still significantly restricted by the low H2O2 yield, which is mainly ascribed to the intrinsic thermodynamic limitations to selectively form H2O2, and the operational restrictions to increase the H2 concentration to prevent any potential H2/O2 mixture explosion. The H2/O2 ratio is also of prime importance in improving catalytic activity as well as in securing safe operation [18]. It is well known that the addition of inorganic acids or halides efficiently increases the H2O2 yield by suppressing the H2O2 decomposition/hydrogenation or poisoning unselective active sites [12,19–21]. However, the use of caustic additives may cause corrosion of equipment and adds separation processes, which considerably reduces the benefits of the DSHP process. Therefore, to successfully implement the DSHP process, the H2O2 yield should be increased without compromising the economic and environmental attractiveness of the process [1,10]. In recent decades a variety of elegant catalyst designs were attempted to improve the reaction performance by tuning the physicochemical properties of the active metals, the supports, and the combinations thereof [6,12,15,16,22–36]. It is common knowledge in heterogeneous catalyst design that the characteristics of the support materials exert a significant effect on the catalytic activity, not only for the DSHP reaction. Extensive studies were devoted to improve catalysts by modifying the surface of support materials [12,37–42]. Solid acid supports were actively explored by incorporating acidic functional groups into the surface to provide materials that attain a high H2O2 yield under safe and non-corrosive reaction conditions [43–51]. For this purpose, we have been studied a range of potential solid acid supports, i.e., exfoliated niobium oxide nanosheets [52], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [53], resins [54,55], hyper-crosslinked porous polymer [56], and carbon materials [57–59]. It was observed that all supports had their own strengths and weaknesses. For example, the well-defined MOF structure with sufficient acid sites on metal nodes and/or linkers is of obvious benefit, promoting the reaction. However, their structure is susceptible to oxidative decomposition by the generated H2O2. Therefore, it seems necessary to improve their stability in terms of long-term use. The undesirable H2O2-induced oxidative degradation should also be considered in the case of polymeric materials [10]. On the other hand, carbon materials are attractive in terms of their price, easy availability, and high stability under extreme reaction conditions [60–63]. However, the performance of carbon-supported palladium (Pd/C) catalysts for the DSHP reaction remains unsatisfactory due to the irregular and heterogeneous textural properties of carbon materials. There were only few systematic studies to elucidate the effect of the carbon support surface on the catalytic DSHP reaction activity. In this study, we modified the surface of activated carbon and carbon black by sulfonation, and systematically investigated the effect of the modified carbon support on the physicochemical properties of the active Pd metal during catalyst preparation. Furthermore, the activity of the resulting Pd/C catalysts with respect to the DSHP reaction was determined. It was revealed that fine tuning of the carbon surface characteristics is extremely important to maximize the activity of the carbon-supported Pd catalyst for the DSHP reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Activated carbon (Norit) and carbon black (Vulcan XC-72) were obtained from Cabot Corporation. Tetraamminepalladium (II) nitrate solution (Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2, 5 wt% Pd) was purchased from Strem. Ferroin indicator ([Fe(C12C8N2)3]SO4, 0.1 wt% in H2O) was supplied from Sigma-Aldrich. Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, 99.5 %) and methyl yellow (indicator, 98 %) were obtained from Kanto Chemical and Tokyo Chemical, respectively. 0.1 N Cerium (IV) sulfate solution (Ce(SO4)2) was purchased from Merck Millipore. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 34.5 %), sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3, 99 %), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 35 %–37 %), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 98 %), sodium chloride (NaCl, 99.5 %), phenolphthalein (C20H14O4, 98 %), ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.5 %), and methanol (CH3OH, 99.9 %) were procured from Samchun Chemicals, Korea. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 98 %) was purchased from Daejung Chemicals, Korea. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Sulfonic acid groups were incorporated on activated carbon (AC) or carbon black (CB) surfaces following a previous report with slight modification [64]. For example, 10 g of AC and 200 mL of H2SO4 (98 %) were sequentially charged into a 500 mL three-necked round bottom flask connected to a condenser. The slurry solution was slowly agitated for 30 min to ensure the homogeneous dispersion of AC, and to suppress any hot spot formation during sulfonation at an elevated temperature. The sulfuric acid treatment was carried out at 423 K for 12 h under N2. After cooling to an ambient temperature (293−298 K), the resulting slurry was washed thoroughly with hot water until the pH remained unchanged. The sulfonated activated carbon (SAC) was dried at 383 K for 12 h. Sulfonated carbon black (SCB) was prepared in a similar manner. A series of carbon supported palladium catalysts were prepared by the impregnation of a cationic palladium precursor on the untreated carbons (AC and CB) or their sulfonated ones (S-AC and S-CB). Typically, a predetermined aqueous solution of Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 (Pd intake 2 wt%) was added dropwise to a carbon support (1 g) with thorough mixing. After aging at an ambient temperature for 12 h, the as-prepared catalyst was dried at 393 K for 4 h, and sequentially calcined under flowing air (100 mL/min) at 523 K for 3 h. For further reduction, the calcined catalyst was exposed to a flowing 50 % N2/H2 mixed gas (100 mL/min) at temperatures ranging from 373 to 573 K for 3 h. 2.3 Characterization The changes in the physicochemical characteristics of the carbon surface by sulfonation were thoroughly analyzed using various characterization methods. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of untreated and sulfonated carbon supports were determined by N2 physisorption using a BELSORP-Max (BEL, Japan) at 77 K. All samples were degassed overnight at 423 K under vacuum prior to the experiments. The BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) and MP (micropore analysis) models were applied to calculate the surface area and pore volume of a sample, respectively. The approximate content of oxygenates and sulfonic acid groups on the carbon support was determined by Boehm’s titration method [65–67]. Three basic reagents such as NaOH, Na2CO3, and NaHCO3 were used to neutralize the surface functionalities of carbon materials based on their acid strength. For this purpose, carbon material (0.5 g) was treated with 0.01 N solution (20 mL) of each reagent for 24 h. After separating the carbon material, acid-base titration was performed to determine the base amount of the solution with phenolphthalein indicator. It is well known that while NaOH neutralizes all sulfonic acids, carboxylic acids, lactones, and phenol, Na2CO3 neutralizes carboxylic acids and lactones, and NaHCO3 neutralizes carboxylic acids [67]. Element Analysis (C, H, O, N, S) was carried out using a FlashSmart Elemental Analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS-IR) analysis of the carbon surface was performed using an FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50, Thermo Fischer Science, USA) equipped with a diffuse IR chamber (Pike Technology, USA). The electron binding energies of sulfur and palladium in the catalyst were measured using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo VG. Scientific MultiLab 2000, U.K.) with a step increment of 0.1 eV at a pass energy of 50 eV using an Al anode. The C 1s XPS peak at 284.6 eV was used as a reference to determine the peak positions in the sample. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was carried out on a Malvern Panalytical Empyrean high-resolution X-ray diffractometer equipped with CuK α (λ = 1.54 Å) radiation. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were taken using a field emission transmission microscope (Tecnai G2 F30, USA). The Pd nanoparticle size and distribution were measured using STEM images. 2.4 Activity test The DSHP reaction was performed in the absence of any caustic additives, as described in our previous reports with minor modification [56–59]. For example, 20 mg of catalyst and 50 g of a methanol/water solution (80 wt% MeOH) were charged into a 100 mL jacketed high-pressure reactor (Büchiglas Picoclave, Switzerland) connected to a circulator (Julabo F25-HF, Germany). After the temperature was cooled down to 275 K under nitrogen, mixed H2/N2 (5 mol% H2), and O2/N2 (20 mol% O2) gases were supplied simultaneously to the reactor for 15 min. After pressurized and stabilized at 30 bar, the reaction was carried out for 1 h under vigorous stirring (1200 rpm). During the reaction, the reactor pressure (30 bar) and the total gas flow rate (40 mL/min, H2/O2/N2 = 3.8/5.0/91.2) were maintained. At the end of the reaction, the reactor pressure was relieved to atmospheric level and the reaction solution was drained from the reactor for analysis. The H2O2 concentration was measured by titrating the reaction product using a cerium sulfate (Ce(SO4)2) solution in presence of ferroin indicator. To calculate the H2 conversion, the off-gas was analyzed by using an Agilent 6890 N gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a Carboxen-1010 PLOT capillary column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). H2O2 selectivity were calculated based on the determined H2O2 and H2 concentrations. H2O2 productivity was defined as the amount of H2O2 produced per hour divided by the Pd content (mmol H2O2/g Pd h). 2.5 H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation were carried out at 275 K for 1 h under atmospheric pressure. For H2O2 decomposition, 50 g of a 1 wt% H2O2 methanol/water solution was poured into a three-necked round bottom flask containing 20 mg of catalyst. After cooling to 275 K under nitrogen, the resulting solution was magnetically stirred for 1 h. H2O2 hydrogenation was performed in a similar manner under H2 bubbling (10 mL/min). During the H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation tests, the liquid samples periodically extracted from reactor were titrated to investigate the changes in the H2O2 concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Changes in the physicochemical properties of carbon supports by sulfonation Two representative carbon materials, activated carbon (AC) and carbon black (CB), were used for the surface modification. Sulfonic acid groups were incorporated on these distinctive carbon materials by sulfonation using H2SO4 at elevated temperature. To determine changes in the distribution of the oxygenates and sulfonic acid groups on the AC or CB surface obtained by sulfonation, qualitative and/or quantitative analysis were carried out using chemical titration, DRIFTS-IR, and XPS. As summarized in Table 1 , the textural and chemical properties of the sulfonated carbon surface were highly dependent on the carbon support used. While the surface area of SAC was reduced by sulfonation due to the incorporated − SO3H groups, there was little change in the case of SCB. Fig. 1 presents the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the untreated and sulfonated samples. AC (red) and SAC (green) exhibited type-I isotherms with type H4 hysteresis loops. The CB (blue) and SCB (orange) supports showed type III with hysteresis loops of type H3, according to IUPAC classification [68]. Titration and XPS analysis also suggested that the characteristics of the incorporated functional groups differed with respect to the carbon support types. In the case of SAC, approximately 0.2 mmol/g of oxygen-containing functional groups were incorporated, and 38 % of them were carboxylic or sulfonic acid groups. On the other hand, small amounts of oxygenates and sulfonic acid groups (0.03 mmol/g) were incorporated on CB by sulfonation, while approximately 63 % of all functional groups consisted of acids. The difference in the sulfonated carbon surface was also confirmed by DRIFTS-IR analysis. The DRIFTS-IR spectra of SAC clearly exhibited characteristic peaks and bands ascribed to sulfonic acid groups as shown in Fig. 2 . The vibration bands at about 1150 and 1040 cm−1 were assigned to the OSO [69,70] and SO [69–71] stretching of the SO3H group, respectively. The large peak around 1100 cm−1 may also be ascribed to the asymmetric SO2 stretching [72]. The legible peak at 1220 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching of the phenolic OH group [73], which indicated that a large amount of hydroxyl group was incorporated into the activated carbon surface by sulfonation. In the case of SCB, diffusion reflectance intensities of ν(SO3H) and ν(OH) were very low indicating insignificant hydroxyl and sulfonic acid group contents. 3.2 Preparation and characterization of the Pd/C catalysts To examine the influence of the carbon support of the palladium catalysts on the DSHP reaction, a series of Pd/C catalysts were prepared using untreated (AC and CB) and sulfonated (S-AC and S-CB) carbons under different calcination and reduction conditions. The list of prepared Pd/C catalysts is summarized in Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 3 , the PXRD analysis of the Pd/C catalysts implied that the Pd crystallinity was significantly affected by the carbon support type as well as the heat treatment conditions. No appreciable PdO and Pd peaks were observed for the Pd/AC series (Fig. 3 (a)), which indicated that Pd nanoparticles (NPs) smaller than approximately 5 nm [74] were formed regardless of sulfonation and heat treatment conditions. The PXRD patterns of the Pd/CB series (Fig. 3(b)) clearly showed that the heat treatment condition determined the oxidation state of Pd. For example, the strong PdO (101) peak at 2θ = 34° observed for the Pd/CB and Pd/SCB catalysts indicated that most of the Pd changed to PdO after calcination. After subsequent reduction, the characteristic PdO peak completely disappeared, and two peaks ascribed to Pd (111) and Pd (200) were observed at 40.1° and 46.5° (2θ), respectively. The result suggested that most of the PdO was reduced to metallic Pd. Compared to the Pd/AC series, the strong and broad bandwidths of the PdO (101), Pd (111), and Pd (200) peaks suggested that larger Pd NPs were formed on the CB and SCB supports regardless of the calcination and reduction conditions. The estimated Pd NP sizes based on the Scherer equation were approximately 6−10 nm. The HAADF-STEM images of the Pd/C catalysts and their Pd NP size distributions are presented in Fig. 4 . While small Pd NPs ranging from 2 to 3 nm were obtained in the Pd/AC series, relatively larger and polydispersed Pd NPs (6–13 nm) were formed in the Pd/CB series. These results agreed well with the estimated Pd NP sizes based on the PXRD data, and clearly showed that AC with a higher surface area was superior to CB resulting in smaller Pd NPs. Moreover, the decreased Pd NP sizes on the SAC and SCB implied that sulfonation provided smaller Pd NPs because the higher amount of oxygenated and sulfonated functional groups on the carbon surface potentially increased the selective adsorption sites for the cationic Pd ion [57,58]. The Pd NP sizes slightly increased after the reduction regardless of support types, possibly due to sintering during reduction. Fig. 5 shows the XPS analysis of Pd/C catalysts to examine the variations in the electronic state of Pd by calcination and subsequent reduction. The Pd 3d XPS spectra of the Pd/C catalysts indicated that the heat treatment condition determined the oxidation state of Pd. The two strong peaks around 337.9 and 343.5 eV observed for the calcined catalysts were attributed to the Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 peaks of Pd2+ [54,55], which suggested that most of the Pd existed in the oxidized form after calcination, regardless of carbon type and sulfonation. After reduction Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 peaks shifted to lower binding energies, which indicated the enhanced metallic state of Pd upon reduction. It is noted that the electron binding energy of the supported metallic Pd was relatively higher than that of unsupported bulk metallic Pd phase (∼335 eV), which might be ascribed to the charge transfer from palladium to supporting materials [75,76]. The Pd2+/Pd° ratios of the Pd/C catalysts clearly show the effect of heat treatment conditions on the electronic nature of Pd (Fig. 5 (c)). However, it is noted that not all palladium was reduced, and 25–40 % of it remained in oxidized form. Moreover, the increased Pd2+/Pd° ratios observed for the Pd species on the sulfonated carbon supports might result from the interaction between Pd NPs and the sulfonic acid groups on the carbon supports [42,54]. The S 2p XPS spectra presented in Fig. 6 shows the changes in the chemical states of sulfur during the catalyst preparation. For SCB, the two deconvoluted peaks of S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 around 168.3 and 171.2 eV indicated that sulfur existed as sulfonic acid on the CB surface [77,78]. In the case of SAC, additional peaks of S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 around 164.5 and 166.3 eV were assigned to the thiol group [79] suggesting the incomplete oxidation of sulfur during sulfonation and the existence of both − SO3H and − SH groups on the AC surface. While the degree of sulfonation was improved by changing the sulfonation conditions, additional experiments were not performed to prevent unfavorable structural decomposition of the carbon support under extended and more severe sulfonation conditions [51,66]. The chemical state of sulfur on AC was significantly affected by the reduction. While S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2 peaks for − SO3H groups were maintained after calcination (Pd/SAC), these peaks were largely reduced and the corresponding peaks for the − SH group increased (Pd/S-ACR). The results indicated that large amount of − SO3H group as well as palladium was reduced upon H2 addition. In the case of S-CBR, partial reduction of the incorporated − SO3H groups could not be confirmed because peak deconvolution of the S 2p XPS spectrum for the -SH group was difficult due to the low signal to noise ratio. However, accelerated H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation rates in the presence of the Pd/S-CBR catalyst implied that the − SO3H groups on CB were also affected by reduction (will be discuss later). As described above, high H+ ion concentration in the DSHP reaction solution is advantageous in improving H2O2 selectivity by limiting H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation. Therefore, measuring the pH of the reaction solution in the presence of a catalyst can be a useful method to evaluate the potential of a solid acid support for enhancing H2O2 selectivity. In this context, pH changes of the reaction solution were investigated by adding various Pd/C catalysts before the activity test. As shown in Fig. 7 , incorporation of − SO3H groups on the carbon support effectively decreased the pH of the reaction solution regardless of the type of carbon support. By the addition of SAC with a high − SO3H group content, the pH decreased to approximately 3.4, which implied the promising potential of SAC as a solid acid support. On the other hand, while SCB efficiently decreased the pH of the reaction solution, the slightly acidic pH (ca. 6.2) suggested that the beneficial effect of the introduction of − SO3H groups on the CB surface is limited. It was also observed that the introduction of palladium on carbon supports and subsequent heat treatments affected the pH of the reaction solution. In the cases of Pd/AC and Pd/ACR, the pH of the reaction solution gradually increased after Pd impregnation/calcination and subsequent reduction. The considerable pH gap between SAC and Pd/SAC is ascribed to the interaction between the Pd NPs and the − SO3H group. For Pd/S-ACR, as observed in the S 2p XPS analysis, the partial reduction of the − SO3H groups on SAC additionally increased the pH of the reaction solution. On the contrary, the relatively high pH of the reaction solution in the presence of CB was decreased by the impregnation with Pd. For the Pd/SCB series, a negligible pH change indicated that effect of the surface − SO3H groups on the pH of reaction solution was maintained after reduction. 3.3 Direct synthesis of H2O2 The activity of the various Pd/C catalysts for the DSHP reaction were evaluated in the absence of any corrosive promoters. As presented in Fig. 8 , it was revealed that not only the intrinsic features of the carbon supports but also their modified surface properties by sulfonation and the changed electronic nature of Pd by different heat treatments significantly affected the reaction performance. Among the carbon supports used, AC achieved a higher H2O2 productivity and selectivity than CB regardless of sulfonation and heat treatment conditions. The H2O2 productivity and selectivity of the Pd/AC catalyst were approximately two to three times higher than those of Pd/CB. Since the electronic Pd properties were considerably more affected by the heat treatment than by the carbon support types, as shown in the Pd 3d XPS analysis (Fig. 5), the noticeably different catalytic activity between Pd/AC and Pd/CB might be related to their different Pd NP sizes, which were 2–3 nm for Pd/AC and 6–13 nm for Pd/CB. The higher surface area of AC with a larger number of functional groups was advantageous and provided more selective adsorption sites for cationic Pd precursor ions and therefore formed smaller Pd NPs. While such small Pd NPs within the sub-nano domain might preferentially promote H2O2 formation, larger Pd NPs might accelerate the undesirable O2 dissociation and thus mainly produce H2O [57,80,81]. The modified surface properties of the carbon support ascribed to sulfonation also significantly affected the reaction performance. Irrespective to the type of carbon support or heat treatment conditions, the H2O2 selectivity increased after sulfonation. The enhanced H2O2 selectivity clearly indicated that both SAC and SCB act as efficient solid acid supports. Although the number of sulfonic acid groups introduced by sulfonation was smaller in the case of the Pd/SCB catalyst, and the pH of the reaction solution remained neutral, the H2O2 selectivity was as high as 72 %, which is 2.2 times higher than that obtained in the presence of the Pd/CB catalyst. These results imply that not only the size of Pd NPs, but also the presence of sulfonic acid group is of prime importance in attaining a high H2O2 selectivity. On the other hand, the reduced H2 conversion in the case of Pd/SAC might be ascribed to the partially decomposed activated carbon structure caused by sulfonation. Whereas sulfonation changed the surface properties of the carbon support, additional heat treatments after Pd impregnation determined the electronic properties of Pd NPs and their sizes. The reduction of Pd/C catalysts noticeably increased H2 conversion and reduced markedly the H2O2 selectivity, which might be ascribed to the changed electronic properties of Pd clusters, such as the improved metallic state of Pd and the slightly increased NP sizes, as confirmed by XPS and STEM analysis. However, it is noted that both H2 conversion and H2O2 selectivity increased in the case of Pd/S-ACR, implying that fine tuning of the reduction condition is necessary to improve the catalytic activity. In this regard, the Pd/C catalysts were reduced in the temperature range of 373–573 K, and their catalytic activities were evaluated. As shown in Fig. 9 , the reaction performance of the Pd/C catalysts significantly depended on the reduction temperature. As the temperature increased, a tradeoff between H2 conversion and H2O2 selectivity was observed, because more Pd was reduced at the higher temperature. Although the H2 conversion increased as the reduction temperature increased, the H2O2 selectivity considerably decreased over the Pd/ACR catalyst, which significantly reduced the H2O2 yield. In the case of Pd/S-ACR reduced between 373 and 473 K, only the H2 conversion increased while the H2O2 selectivity remained constant. As a result, the H2O2 yield increased from 11 to 21 %. However, H2O2 selectivity sharply decreased in the presence of the same catalyst reduced at 573 K. On the other hand, the H2O2 selectivity of the Pd/S-CBR catalysts decreased even more as a function of reduction temperature. Considering that there is little difference in the oxidation states of Pd or Pd2+/Pd0 ratios between the Pd/S-ACR and Pd/S-CBR catalysts, it seems that the different trends in the H2O2 yield of these catalysts depending on the reduction temperature might be attributed to the different surface characteristics of the carbon supports. These results demonstrate that the properties of the carbon support, regardless of whether it is intrinsic or modified, markedly affects the reducibility of palladium and therefore the activity of the reduced Pd/C catalysts. The effect of the Pd NP size and Pd2+/Pd° ratio on the H2O2 selectivity is summarized in Fig. 10 . It is clearly demonstrated that the H2O2 selectivity strongly depends on the Pd NP sizes (Fig. 10 (a)). As the Pd NP size increased, the H2O2 selectivity considerably decreased for the Pd/AC series, except for Pd/S-ACR. This reduction in H2O2 selectivity was also observed for the Pd/CB series. However, the H2O2 selectivity of Pd/S-CB was significantly higher than that of Pd/ACR having a smaller Pd NP size, which implies that factors other than Pd NP size noticeably affected the reaction performance. Fig. 10 (b) shows that a higher Pd2+/Pd° ratio provided a higher H2O2 selectivity. However, the highest selectivity was obtained over Pd/S-ACR, which exhibited a lower Pd2+/Pd° ratio compared to that of Pd/S-CB. These results indicate that the collective effects of Pd NP size, Pd electronic state, and physicochemical properties of the carbon support primarily maximize the H2O2 selectivity. It was reported that geometric and electronic changes in the Pd NPs during a reaction exerted large influence on the reaction performance, and N-incorporated carbon support was advantageous in stabilizing any beneficial Pd species which promoted the selective formation of H2O2 [74]. It seems that the sulfonated carbon surface might play such a benign role in stabilizing the selective Pd species. More detailed study in this matter is in due course. In Table 3 , the reaction performance of the Pd/S-ACR catalyst was compared with those of previously reported Pd catalysts supported on various carbon materials, such as activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, carbon black, ordered mesoporous carbon, and carbon nanofiber. The excellent reaction performance of the Pd/S-ACR catalyst in the absence of any caustic additives clearly demonstrates the promising aspect of sulfonated carbon-supported Pd catalyst for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide. 3.4 H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation tests Since all the reaction pathways involved in the DSHP reaction are thermodynamically favorable and catalyzed by Pd, not only the H2O2 formation, but also the efficient suppression of its subsequent decomposition and hydrogenation are important to maximize H2O2 selectivity. In this context, H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation tests were performed in the presence of Pd/C catalysts. Similar to the DSHP reaction, Fig. 11 shows that the degree of decomposition and hydrogenation was considerably affected by the physicochemical features of the active metal, the carbon supports, and the combination thereof. The observed faster H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation rates over the Pd/CB series might be ascribed to their larger Pd NP sizes [57,59,80]. DFT calculation indicated that Pd NP size larger than 2.5 nm can accelerate both H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation [80]. Moreover, irrespective to the type of carbon support and sulfonation, the increase in reduced Pd metal accelerated both H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation, and therefore resulted in a decreased H2O2 selectivity [38,87,88]. The increased H2 conversion over the reduced Pd/C catalysts indicates that H2 might be concurrently used in the H2O2 hydrogenation as well as in the DSHP reaction (see Fig. 8). Sulfonation was also efficient in suppressing H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation, indicating that the use of a solid acid support is beneficial for high H2O2 selectivity. The reduced decomposition and hydrogenation rates over the Pd/SCB catalyst also suggested that even a small amount of sulfonic acid groups on the CB surface noticeably affected the H2O2 decomposition, hydrogenation, as well as its formation, as seen with the DSHP reaction. However, the faster rates observed over the Pd/S-CBR catalyst indicated that the beneficial sulfonation effect substantially decreased after reduction. Based on the discussion above, it is concluded that the synergistic property combination of active metal and carbon support is a prerequisite to realize a highly active and selective Pd/C catalyst for the DSHP reaction. 3.5 Catalyst recycling Since reusability of a catalyst is important as much as its activity, recycle test runs using the Pd/S-ACR catalyst were carried out to examine the stability of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 12 , while H2 conversion slightly increased, both H2O2 productivity and selectivity gradually decreased during the recycle runs. Partial loss of catalyst during catalyst recovery was inevitable, and normally, ca. 85 % of catalyst was recovered after the third runs. The partial loss of catalyst acting as a solid acid support slightly increased the pH of reaction solution (ca. 4.5–5), which might decrease the H2O2 selectivity during the recycle runs. Electronic and geometric properties of Pd could be changed during a reaction, and thus affected the catalytic activity. To check the possibility, XPS and HAADF-STEM analysis were carried out again for the used Pd/S-ACR catalyst. It was found that there were little appreciable changes in the oxidation state and NP size of Pd as shown in Fig. 13 . However, it seems that the reduced activity might be partially affected by the subtle changes in the electronic and geometric features of Pd as well as catalyst loss during the recycle runs. The ICP analysis of the reaction solution implied that there was negligible Pd leaching during the catalyst recycle runs. 4 Conclusion A systematic study was performed to create a highly active and selective Pd/C catalyst for the DSHP reaction. For this purpose, the sulfonation of activated carbon and carbon black was carried out. Changes in the geometric and electronic nature of Pd induced by the surface properties of the carbon supports and heat treatments were investigated. Based on the systematic characterization of Pd/C catalysts prepared at various conditions in combination with their performance for the DSHP reaction, it was revealed that the NP size and oxidation state of Pd played crucial roles in the reaction performance. Moreover, the use of a sulfonated carbon support suppressed favorably the H2O2 decomposition and hydrogenation, increasing the H2O2 selectivity. These results clearly demonstrate that geometric, electronic, and synergistic effects provided by the carbon-supported Pd catalysts resulted in high H2O2 selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Although carbon-supported palladium catalysts have been generally used for the direct synthesis of H2O2 (DSHP), the low H2O2 selectivity remains a challenge. In this work, it was systematically studied how the sulfonated carbon surface affects the physicochemical properties of Pd during catalyst preparation, and thereby affects the catalytic activity of Pd/C for the DSHP reaction. Nano-sized Pd particles (about 2–3 nm) with a high Pd2+/Pd0 ratio resulted in a high H2O2 selectivity. The sulfonated carbon material acted as an efficient solid acid support and enhanced the H2O2 selectivity. Fine-tuning the Pd properties on the sulfonated carbon support significantly improved the H2O2 selectivity by as much as 87 % in the absence of caustic promoters, which clearly demonstrates that the synergistic combination of the active metal properties and that of the carbon support are extremely important to realize a highly active and selective carbon-supported palladium catalyst for the DSHP reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Geometric, electronic, and synergistic effect in the sulfonated carbon-supported Pd catalysts for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide
